author: Brandon Schwartz
bottom_line: Strong winds drifting new snowfall will create potentially unstable slabs of snow near ridgetops and in gully features. Areas of unstable wet snow may form in areas that receive rain on snow or afternoon sun. Move cautiously around avalanche terrain where wind drifted snow is depositing or where signs of surface wet snow exist.
hazard_discussion: Massive cornices exist along many ridgelines. Some have deep cracks behind them. A substantial warming event leading to some large cornice collapses is expected to occur during the Saturday to Monday timeframe.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
Ridgetop winds increased overnight and are strong in speed out of the SW this morning. New snowfall today, mainly near the Sierra Crest will drift and deposit on the leeward side of ridgetops and into gully features. Unstable wind slabs are possible in above treeline and near treeline terrain. The vast majority of new wind slab development will occur across NW-N-NE-E-SE aspects today.

Use clues such as blowing snow, cornices, wind drifts, recent avalanches, and snow surface cracking to identify slopes of concern. Move cautiously around avalanche terrain where the potential for unstable wind slabs exists.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wind Slab
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wind Slab avalanches are the release of a cohesive layer of snow (a slab) formed by the wind. Wind typically transports snow from the upwind sides of terrain features and deposits snow on the downwind side. Wind slabs are often smooth and rounded and sometimes sound hollow, and can range from soft to hard. Wind slabs that form over a persistent weak layer (surface hoar, depth hoar, or near-surface facets) may be termed Persistent Slabs or may develop into Persistent Slabs.

forecast_avalanche_problems.discussion:
There are a few possible scenarios for a wet loose avalanche problem to develop today on any aspect. One scenario is rising snow levels leading to rain on new snow. A second scenario is rapid warming during any sun breaks that occur this afternoon between periods of snow showers. A third scenario is very wet new snow in the first 1,000' or so above the rain/snow line today.

Rollerballs and pinwheels are indications that this avalanche problem is present. Consider moving to slopes less steep than about 35 degrees in slope angle to reduce the risk of triggering a wet loose avalanche.

forecast_avalanche_problems.name: Wet Loose
forecast_avalanche_problems.problem_description: Wet Loose avalanches are the release of wet unconsolidated snow or slush. These avalanches typically occur within layers of wet snow near the surface of the snowpack, but they may quickly gouge into lower snowpack layers. Like Loose Dry Avalanches, they start at a point and entrain snow as they move downhill, forming a fan-shaped avalanche. Other names for loose-wet avalanches include point-release avalanches or sluffs. Loose Wet avalanches can trigger slab avalanches that break into deeper snow layers.
